args:
Valyx's army, which marched north to deal with
invaders, has been wiped out. Having laid him
low, the enigmatic Nedrick formulates a plan to
use his fallen foe. Meanwhile, with events at the
palace leaving them in disarray, the prince's
party heads for the border via a mountain pass.
You are hailed as a warrior without peer\nin all of Alberia; I see your skills do not\nbely that reputation.
Your troops fight with both great fury and\nunmatched discipline, and your military\nmind is keen.
R-run, General Valyx... You need not\nmeet your end this day...
And behold the faith your subordinates\nplace in you! It makes this situation\nall the more incomprehensible.
Yet with all this strength at your disposal,\nyou still refuse to attempt the throne.
You did not challenge your siblings,\nand even treated with the Other.\nWhere do your true motives lie?
If you do not answer me, General Valyx,\nI will take the lives of each and every one\nof your subordinates.

A man of arms knows his place to be on
the field of battle. But sometimes he looks
up and finds his people have been pressed
into a fight that is not their own.
The duty and burden of royalty is to\nsafeguard their powerless charges.

In other words, you attempted to avoid
conflict in order to save your people,
and in doing so chose to abandon
your own ambition.

Placing a people above oneself is the
highest form of virtue and honorâ€”but
failing to grasp the meaning of one's
own strength is the basest of folly.
You are a man of unlimited discipline,\nyet use that power merely to hold your\ntrue feelings at bay.
You are wracked with doubt regarding\nwhether or not you ought to have sought\nthe throne and spurned the Other.

But more than that, you are envious.
You begrudge your brother, the seventh
scion, who now finds himself so very close
to claiming the crown as his own.
Permit me grant you a position that\nbetter suits your talents, fourth scion.
The time has come to release your\ntrue instinctsâ€”and your true ambition.
My brothers Phares and Beren appeared\nin the palace, put an end to Morsayati,\nand vanished as quickly as they arrived.
Moments later, we were attacked by Agito.\nAnd though we tried to get Zethia to safety,\nshe was stolen away by a mysterious man.
Before he left, he gave Elisanne a message\ntelling me to come to a checkpoint on the\nnorthern Grastaea border.
Though everything around us was chaos,\nwe decided to head for the border at once.
We'll arrive at the checkpoint once we\ncross through this mountainâ€”but is\nZethia really going to be there?
It does smell like a trap, darling.
Elisanne, the man who stole Zethia away\ndefinitely told us to come to this particular\ncheckpoint, correct?
Yes. Of that, there is no mistake.
And you really don't remember anything\nabout what the guy was like?
I beg forgiveness once more.\nIt...it all happened so fast.
Perhaps he has some connection to Agito.
Or he could be with a completely different\nforce. It's probably best not to make any\nconclusions at this point.
Amen to that. Between The Other, Beren,\nPhares, and Agito, I'm losin' track of the\njerks what wanna kill us lately.
We're up to our eyeballs in plots and\ndouble-crosses. Just lemme stick an\naxe in somebody already, sheesh!
Sussing out that man's identity can wait;\nour priority is to reach the checkpoint.
Yeah! We gotta get Zethia back!
You're right. We just have to press on\nand hope for the best.
Move out, everyoneâ€”and keep both eyes\npeeled for anything suspicious.
